author: Nosefuroughtto
body:
I find it odd to consider Amazon like Standard Oil. SO derived it’s monopolistic power through acquisitions of rival refineries and distributors; purely horizontal integration, followed by outright price fixing.

Amazon is absolutely massive, but the growth method and diversity of markets they participate in distinguishes them from old trust oriented monopolies. I’m terms of AWS, the majority of growth was organic, and would not have ran afoul of antitrust law back in its hay day, such as when US v. Aluminum Co. of America was prevailing law.

An attempt to break up Amazon by business segment would probably fail due to the shift since the 70’s from Per Se Antitrust violations to the Rule of Reason. They aren’t dominating any given sector to the point that a court could likely prove anti-consumer behavior, which has increasingly become the prime factor.

Online shopping has a fairly rich market with Walmart, Home Depot, Best Buy, wayfair, etc.; physical stores obviously have Walmart and target being dominant; subscription services are still beaten by Netflix and Google, with Disney catching up fast; AWS competes with Oracle, Microsoft snd Google.

Overall I think the justifications for breaking up Amazon are weak in light of the method of growth, the fact that they aren’t shutting out competitors in any given industry right now, and our much more consumer viewpoint focus on antitrust enforcement.

author: HulksInvinciblePants
body:
>Good thing you can share your wisdom then, oh eternal oracle of the market.

Hmmm. I'm don't recall trying to predict when the market will crash and I post quite a bit, when I'm qualified to do so. My advice this time was making users aware of how bad this post was and how illiterates most this sub is. 

>Surely you know more then Dalio, what books have you written?

L. Ron Hubbard and Cosby wrote books too. That's a pretty low bar. 

>Gold is a old-school store of value by definition and as we saw in 2020 (amongst others) a great asset during times of uncertainty and crashes. Buy it during calm times, sell during fearful times.

Yeah, that's not accurate. Gold is not a hedge, its a portfolio diversifier. It's market correlation is 0.02, which is an unattached, positive number...not the large negative correlation you would hope for from a hedge. It did absolutely nothing during the dot-com bubble and probably hurt most investors that held during 2020.

author: aimaguru
body:
Yeah I'm not the oracle for ya when it comes to trying to time the market :)   


I've been mostly right on my directional plays but wrong too many times to count on "oh I'll just sell here and up my position on the way down" or "this is DEFINITELY never going higher than this" (cries in AMC)  


One framework I've seen (maybe rementioned on Fatty's DD) is would you be more upset about selling at X and it runs up to \[price target\] or holding and it dropping to \[your worst case thesis\].   


Personally (my risk tolerance and thesis re: ATOS, not necessarily yours) is that I like the stock enough and am enjoying the IV selling calls enough that, although I'd love a quick 4-10x pop, I'm okay with holding for the longer term, averaging down, and waiting for phase 3 and/or an acquisition down the line.

author: CodeMaitre
body:
ORCL One Year and 6 Month Chart - [https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg](https://imgur.com/S6dI2gg)

It has pretty much made its move, you'd be buying in the "sell" area statistically. You're correct, the buy zone is  always below regression trend (average) line in the middle, so you'd want to snag it if it goes back down to 75-80. Although its true downward potential is the blue -1 deviation line, so 70-73. Deviations change a little bit day to day as more price data is added but right now you'd be buying into an uptrend which is not very safe. You'd basically be betting to get the cherry on top running up to +1 deviations at 88-91.

author: Toys_R_Them
body:
Most of the new growth has been in tech, and tech rarely pays dividends, outside of some stalwarts like MSFT and ORCL.

A lot of those dividend payers are energy companies and REITs, who also underperformed for various pandemic-related reasons.

A portfolio that high in dividends is typically recommended for older people, who need current income and downside protection in case of economic swings, and could care less about potential growth of their portfolio decades from now.

author: OfficialTestikills
body:
I personally invest heavily in Web3 crypto's and crypto projects that help run and keep these crypto's decentralised. 

What's a web3 crypto? These aren't to be confused with junk like Bitcoin that thinks it is a store of value or will become the new financial system, web3 crypto is literally creating the next stage in internet where you don't need to worry about your companies information / personal information / classified documents being stored on a server that is owned and managed by other companies. Web3 splits this up between 100's of validators that all talk to each other and keep this decentralised and secure from attacks. 

There's also ones creating the future of finance. No longer do you need to get bent over by huge interest rates and banks fucking people over whenever they feel like it. DEFI is run by liquidity pools, people like you and I who store our money with the service and as a result get a percentage of the interest rates. These rates always remain low and competitive and go to the people rather than the big banks.

Then you have oracles that power the decentralisation. Oracles gain info from many sources and feed it to the protocol to offer decentralised information. For easy laymans terms, if I wanted a weather oracle, it would gather weather data from 1000's weather stations and news outlets, work out the average forecast and feed that to my protocol. This means my protocol is giving the users the most accurate non-biased information. Just as a high-level. 

So how do you make money from this? Well, let's look at Ethereum just as an example. Every single protect that runs on Ethereum has to pay "gas" fees on each transaction, this is paid in Ethereum. Ethereum already has 1000's of applications including VISA and MasterCard that constantly have a demand for Ethereum in order to operate and pay these gas fees. You as the investor holds the Ethereum they need and this creates supply and demand. Additionally, each time a company pays their gas fees, the gas is "burnt" (meaning Ethereum used to pay for the transaction is burnt) creating deflation. 

Ethereum is just one project, and not one that I personally even invest in that much, but it's one that I'm sure most people have heard of.   
If you want to look at getting some crypto while it's currently on a low and has huge potentially to be the future of a new decentralised internet feel free to use my exchange code. Swyftx is aussie based exchange and you get 20% off fees with my code, plus I get a kick back [https://trade.swyftx.com.au/register/?ref=brentboydskinner](https://trade.swyftx.com.au/register/?ref=brentboydskinner)

&#x200B;

Message me if you want to know more

author: justsomescrub
body:
Not so much diversifying as just straight up killing it. Operating income rose 189% from 2019 to 2020 with eps up 604%. Q1 2021 operating income is up 266% and eps is up 232% from Q1 2020 and it isn't *just* higher margins; Total revenue in 2020 was up 45% from 2019 and Q1 2021 total rev Is up 92% compared to Q1 2020. Oh and the XLNX acquisition or whatever pending china approval.

  
AND there are some tasty insider whispers IF TRUE insinuating next gen GPU performance above and beyond what they expect from Nvidia. FULL STOP. Not at bargain price points, or for certain niche applications just straight up expecting to have the best GPUs on the market next gen. Nvidia having something spicy up their sleeve non-withstanding; you never know with Nvidia.   

  Add in plans to buy back 4 billion worth of shares over the next 4(?) Years with cash on hand and plans for 3nm production by 2024 and everything I hear about AMD makes me think up up up. They have new deals with Samsung for their phones and google/amazon for servers, to add to the pile of deals like making chips for Sony and Microsoft consoles. The future looks bright.

I put 90% of my account in AMD last month when they were hovering around 80$ without a single worry and I haven't unwound my position yet. Hoping for 2021 guidance to be adjusted from 50% to 75% growth to set this thing off again. Or merger approval, whatever comes first.

author: Phaiiroh
body:
AMD shareholders have agreed to acquire XLNX. Instead of paying with cash, they are acquiring the company entirely through stock. The two parties have agreed to a fixed ratio of 1:1.72 to do so. Meaning for every one share of XLNX owned you will receive 1.72 ish shares of AMD. Only if all necessary regulatory bodies approve the acquisition. Currently China is the last approval required until the merger can occur. Technically China can say no and AMD will most likely decide to not go on with the merger.

Because the acquisition is a fixed rate of shares. OP is staring at current market prices the value of one share of XLNX currently is cheaper than 1.72 shares of AMD creating a small discount. So if you were to buy XLNX in an attempt to buy AMD at a cheaper rate it could or could not possibly work out. It’s not a guaranteed thing.

author: stevoacp1
body: i love $AMD, however comparing them to NVDA is not the right move. NVDA is a different beast in that they have the growth of AMD while having the stellar gross margins. Investors are willing to pay a premium for NVDA because of how stellar they are in printing cash and profits. That being said, AMD deserves to be priced closer to NVDA than Intel. I do not believe AMD and Su Bae are focused on catching NVDA, and are more concerned with taking market share from and crushing Intel. All the DDs written on here continue to ignore how important the Xilinx merger is. It was hated on by many, but Su Bae is no moron, she is strongly positioning AMD to dominate the CPU and Semi-Custom solutions. AMD will continue to make progress in the GPU and gaming market but the growth and tendies will come from expanding further into and dominating the server industry and building strong relationships that will establish profits for years, as well as expansion into 5g, aerospace and defense, and AI.

author: mn_sunny
body:
I added shares of XLNX around $115 (AMD equivalent of ~$73) back in May and it was the first time I added to my AMD position since the Covid bottoms (all of the rest of my shares were from 2016 and 2018).

I think AMD is valued more conservatively than the vast majority of other tech/semi companies, but I still think it's ahead of itself. I wouldn't buy it at these current levels, but I'm definitely not selling either (e.g. - I told my family it was safe to buy in May when it got down in the low 70s, but said not to buy above $78-80).

Peter Lynch would approve though given it's EPS growth % is greater than (or equal to) it's P/E multiple.

Do a deep dive of r/amd_stock if you're really interested in AMD--there's a lot of excellent content and some extremely informed people there (I honestly don't follow AMD like I used to b/c I have enough faith in Su/Kumar/Papermaster/Norrod/Wang/etc that I'm just letting my AMD ride and spending all of my time focusing on the rest of my portfolio).

author: Huff0341
body:
Ultimately yes you are correct. The reason for the spread though is the risk involved if the merger doesn’t go through. While most hurdles have been passed I believe they still have China and the US to work through. It’ll tighten up the closer to the merger it gets assuming the hurdles all get jumped. It’s also one of the reasons AMD isn’t popping as much. A lot of  arbiters will short the Buying Company and buy up the target. 

I have not shorted AMD, but I am in on XLNX. Might double my position as I think the risk is worth the it.

author: Latter-Bodybuilder33
body: The goal would be to reach a comparable market cap.. share price by itself is not a comparable metric. AMD is about 1/5th of NVDA in market cap.. and it would have to essentially fire on all cylinders in some kind of volume growth segment: AI, Autonomous, Crypto to get be in same ballpark as NVDA... not only through product pipeline but also getting folks to wean off of comparable nvda products. The xlnx acquisition may increase AMD’s TAM but Nvidia is still king in many segments.. I would be surprised if any of that rapid amd growth happens before 3-4 years ..

author: lefty_vengeance
body:
What reason do you think this will moon.  I expect it was showing nice gains mostly because Xilinx merger felt imminent.  With today's news of China moving forward with phase 2 review, people are going to be much more inclined to take profits:

"SAMR's process involves up to three review periods: Phase One lasts 30 days, Phase Two lasts 60 days, and Phase Three lasts 90 days. The regulator decides at the end of each phase if it's ready to make a decision or if it will move on to the next phase."

So rather than thumbs up, we've got up to 60 days before China gives the go ahead (or delays another 3 fucking months if they so choose).

I don't see it starting to heat back up until a few weeks after earnings.  I predict it sees low 80s before then.

author: rodmcmuffins
body:
AMD has been looking very promising lately, but it still faces the problem of massive dilution after the future Xilinx merger. The $34 billion all stock purchase far outweighs the $4 billion buyback. AMD has value, but it is already expensive before the dilution even with significant revenue growth factored in.  They aren't pulling the margins that could justify a large jump in share price.

Who knows though, an irrational market like ours will probably eat this up anyway.

author: ConditionPrudent1648
body:
I totally recommend leaps options.

Firstly, I made most of my money from leaps.
Share price rises by 25%, my options will have at least 50% profit margin.

Secondly, my holding timeline for stocks is usually 6-12 months. So leaps is great for me 
For my kids, I will buy stocks as I am leaving it for them for the next 15-20 years.

Lastly, don't think u can use margin on options so it prevents me from over leveraging.

PS. I usually sell my options once it get 50% profit margin and move on. Reason is that for me to get 100% profit on options, I will need the stock to rise at least 40-50% which is not really realistic, especially when I have time decay playing against me.

I also buy leaps options on solid companies like Google, amazon, xlnx, baba, jd, Shopify, ttd, crm......etc
I try not to play with meme stocks or companies that do not show at least 4 quarters of profitability.

Best of luck!

author: ConditionPrudent1648
body:
I had some pretty decent results doing leaps call options.
Usually buy ATM call options expiring 200 days and above.

Usually chose blue chip companies that are stable.
Like apple, Shopify, amazon, crm, tsmc, xlnx etc....
Minimum requirement is that the company should be profitable for at least 4 quarters with 15% and above profit margin. These companies tend to rise slowly and steadily with time, so your longer expiration will give it time to play the senerio out 

A 10% rise in stock price will usually translate to a 20% options gain for u. And a 30% stick price increase will translate to a 50% gain for u.

Try to avoid meme stocks and new spac companies and volatile companies as their sudden movement downwards will mean much greater depreciation for your options also. Example, a 30% drop in share price will translate to a 50% drop in your options price.

Every leaps options I have bought till now will be profitable some point in time. U just need to prevent greed and exit accordingly.
Suggestion is to exit around the 50% profit mark or when the option is near the half way mark. Reason is that there is time decay associated with call options, so keeping it to expiry or keeping it too long is disadvantageous to you.

Best of luck!

author: Wyzrobe
body:
I'm way overweight on AMD (and XLNX too, for the merger premium).  

But I would not consider it a forever stock. Technological shifts can change everything in a moment, just a few years ago INTC seemed like a forever stock, and all that's changed with AMD's rise.
